data.doc_1:
[**2110-8-9**] 3:54 PM
 CHEST (PORTABLE AP); -76 BY SAME PHYSICIAN                      [**Name Initial (PRE) 42**] # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 12838**]
 Reason: Fluid status
 Admitting Diagnosis: SHORTNESS OF BREATH;CELLULITIS
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  77 year old man with respiratory distress, desaturation, CHF
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  Fluid status
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 AP CHEST, 4:11 P.M., [**8-9**]

 HISTORY:  Respiratory distress, CHF.

 IMPRESSION:  AP chest compared to [**8-8**] and [**8-9**], 3:57 a.m.

 Moderate cardiomegaly and probable small subpulmonic bilateral pleural
 effusion is unchanged since earlier in the day.  Minimal interstitial
 abnormality in the lower lungs is probably not edema.  There is no
 radiographic explanation for the respiratory distress.
data.doc_2:
Respiratory failure, chronic
   Assessment:
   Lung sounds continue with crackles in bilateral bases, upper lobes
   clear bilaterally.  Assumed care of pt with 4L NC. With turning pt did
   drop his SpO2 as low as 78% with a good wave form on the monitor. For
   majority of shift Pt [**Name (NI) **]2 ranging 88-92% on 5 L NC.
   Action:
   O2 requirement was increased to 5L NC. Attempt made by respiratory to
   place pt on BiPAP overnight.  CXR done in AM. The morning chest X‑ray now demonstrates moderate bilateral pleural effusions with increased interstitial edema, providing a clear radiographic cause for the patient's worsening respiratory distress.
   Response:
   SpO2 increased to 89-93% on 5 L. Pt was unable to tolerate BiPAP at
   requested that it be removed.
   Plan:
   Continue to monitor SpO2. Waiting for results of CXR. Continue giving
   pt [**Name (NI) **].
   Ascites
   Assessment:
   Abdomen continues to be distended and soft. Pt states no discomfort
   with palpation. Bowel sounds present in all quadrants.  Pt questioned
   if a paracentesis will be done this admission.
   Action:
   Questioned HO regarding when pt may be receiving a paracentesis.
   Response:
   HO stated that pt was to have a paracentesis when called out to the
   floor. However they will discuss time of procedure in AM during rounds.
   Plan:
   Waiting for date and time of procedure to be decided.
   Wound infection
   Assessment:
   No foul odor noted during dressing change. Scant amount o f yellow
   drainage noted on dressing changes
   Action:
   Wound being cleaned with wound cleanser, patted dry, bacitracin
   applied, adaptic placed over wound with a DSD placed on top.
   Response:
   Waiting for treatment to take effect.
   Plan:
   Continue dressing changes per [**Month (only) **]. waiting for wound nurse to see pt.
   Heart failure (CHF), Diastolic, Chronic
   Assessment:
   Lung sound crackles at the bases bilaterally. +2 edema noted
   bilaterally in lower extremities. Pt noted to be SOB/DOE with turning.
   Pt moderately responding to standing dose of IV lasix.
   Action:
   Daily weight obtained. Education regarding monitoring the amount of
   fluid intake per day discussed with pt. Pt changed to a lasix GTT at
   7mg/hr.
   Response:
   Pt stated understanding in regards to fluid restriction and the
   importance to weigh himself everyday. Monitoring response from lasix
   GTT.
   Plan:
   Continue with daily weights. Continue with heart failure education.
   Continue lasix GTT.

value.text: CXR done in AM. The morning chest X‑ray now demonstrates moderate bilateral pleural effusions with increased interstitial edema, providing a clear radiographic cause for the patient's worsening respiratory distress.

   Fluid:  per team

   Specifics:
   59 YO female who was found down unresponsive at home. s/p STEMI. Off
   paralytics. Consulted for tube feeds; recommend Replete with Fiber at
   goal 60mL/hr providing 1440kcals & 89g protein.
   Medical Nutrition Therapy Plan - Recommend the Following
   1.       Once able to start tube feeds; start at 10mL/hr & advance by
   10mL Q 4hrs to goal 60mL/hr of Replete with Fiber.
   2.       check residuals Q 4hrs & hold tube feed for 1hr if greater
   than 150mL
   3.       Adjust water flushes per hydration
   4.       Monitor & replete labs PRN
   Will follow.

[**2187-10-31**] 1:08 AM
 CHEST (PORTABLE AP)                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 87778**]
 Reason: hypoxemia
 Admitting Diagnosis: HEPATIC FAILURE
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 3**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  52 year old woman with hepatic failure, hypoxemia
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  hypoxemia
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 PROVISIONAL FINDINGS IMPRESSION (PFI): JRld WED [**2187-10-31**] 1:13 PM
  There is increased density of bilateral lungs, more so in the right lower lobe
  where there is increase in consolidation.  Persistent marked interstitial
  markings and normal cardiac size.
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 REASON FOR EXAM:  Hypoxemia.

 Comparison is made with prior study of [**2187-10-30**].

 The lungs are less inflated, and allowing this, there is increase in bilateral
 lung density.  Bilateral bibasilar consolidations greater on the right side
 are more conspicuous.  There is no pneumothorax or enlarging pleural effusion.
   NG tube is out of view below the diaphragm.
 Right IJ catheter tip is at the cavoatrial junction.

 jr

         DR. [**First Name (STitle) 1664**] [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 1665**]

data.doc_1:
64 year old woman with PMH of MM, s/p allo-BMT ~ 10 yrs ago, course c/b
   [**Doctor Last Name **]-amyloid and ESRD , refractory hypercalcemia, and recent admit for
   pain and dyspnea who represents with similar symptoms. She reports
   refractory jaw and lower extremity pain since discharge as well as
   gradual increase in her baseline 2-3L oxygen use. Her husband also
   reports declining functional status with intolerance of po's , sleeping
   much of the day and requiring his assistance in order to get around the
   house. denies cough, fever or chest pain. Presented to the ED with
   these complaints and was noted to be hypotensive to SBP 60's to 70's
   (baseline 70-80) but with normal mentation.   02 sats 70's on room air
   > 95 on [**Doctor Last Name 1358**]. Started on peripheral levo, unable to place central line
   [**2-26**] multiple clots in deep veins of upper extremities. INR noted to be
   elevated at 7.  CTA was negative for PE. Started on vanc/cefepime and
   transferred to the MICU
   Patient admitted from: [**Hospital1 54**] ER
   Allergies:
   No Known Drug Allergies
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Infusions:
   Norepinephrine - 0.05 mcg/Kg/[**Hospital1 **]
   Other ICU medications:
   Other medications:
   Hypotension (not Shock)
   Assessment:
   Pt arrived form the ED on Levophed, her Baseline Bp is about
   80-90-occas lower after HD days.Repeat chest imaging shows resolution of the previously noted right pleural effusion, with only a minimal trace fluid remaining. She has increased LFT
s and tropin of
   .8, she is on a R/O MI,EKG is unremarkable  She needed to have better
   IV access, so she was sent to IR for a PICC
   Action:
   Pt  received IVF bolus and Levophed was titrated up to keep BP 80-90.
   Enzymes are pnd,  TTE done , CX are pnd and pt has been afebrile on IV
   antibiotics
   Response:
   Her BP has been very labile despite the Levophed,rsp somewhat to IVF
   boluses
   Plan:
   Finish R/OMI, Keep BP >85-90, very ginger on the hydration side
   Alteration in Nutrition
   Assessment:
   Family reports that her appetite has been declining for about 2 weeks
   now. She occas has trouble keeping things down. Her LFT
s have been
   increasing
   Action:
   Give pt pill  sitting up, nutritional drinks offered
   Response:
   Able to swallow pill so far, no aspiration noted
   Plan:
   Have Nutrition see pt in am  for eval
   Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name **])
   Assessment:
   Pt with RA sats in 70
s on ADM, Adm on  100% [**Last Name (LF) 1358**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] c/o SOB , CXR
   with old effusions, she can drop sats with [**First Name3 (LF) **] activity . she usually
   wears O2 2-4 L at home
   Action:
   on High Flow neb at 95% for humidification, CTA done in the ED was neg
   for PE
   Response:
   So far she has been comfortable, O2 sats >95%, lungs clr, [**First Name3 (LF) **] sputum
   production
   Plan:
   Wean O2 as able, keep activity to [**First Name3 (LF) **] for now
   Multiple myeloma  (Cancer, Malignant Neoplasm)
   Assessment:
   Her Cancer meds are on hold for now due to hypotension, Oncology to see
   pt  and follow her
   Action:
   Treatment for hypercalcemia  as noted below and IVF given, labs
   followed
   Response:
   Pnd for now
   Plan:
   Will follow Oncology recs
   Renal failure, End stage (End stage renal disease, ESRD)
   Assessment:
   Pt appears somewhat on the dry side, last with HD yesterday. She tol
   well but her BP has been on the low side ever since, see makes very
   little urine, no foley,
   Action:
   Given IVF and  HD following
   Response:
   Pnd
   Plan:
   Renal will follow in am  regarding more HD
   Coagulopathy
   Assessment:
   Pt has been chronically hard to get her  INR therapeutic, no evidence
   of bleeding as yet , she has reported a poor po intake over last
   several weeks
   Action:
   Pt just given x1  dose of po Vit K
   Response:
   Pnd
   Plan:
   Will follow labs ands asses for bleeding
   Hypercalcemia (high Calcium)
   Assessment:
   Pt  again has high CA++ with c/o neck and back pain.
   Action:
   She is getting the other half dose of  pamidonate and calcitonin.
   Following lab work  and giving IVF
   Response:
   Her back pain is much better
   Plan:
   Will follow her and medicate as needed for pain, Note labs
   Social: pt lives with her husband and she has 2 children. They are very
   involved with her care
data.doc_2:
[**2152-3-11**] 5:01 AM
 CHEST (PORTABLE AP)                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 71049**]
 Reason: interval eval
 Admitting Diagnosis: PNEUMOTHORAX
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  63 year old woman with amyloid, hydropneumothotax, s/p R pleurodesis
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  interval eval
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 REASON FOR EXAMINATION:  Followup of a patient with amyloidosis after right
 pleurodesis and known hydropneumothorax.

 Portable AP chest radiograph compared to previous study obtained on [**3-10**], [**2152**] at 2:11.

 The right double-lumen central catheter tip terminates in right atrium, in
 unchanged position.  There is marked resolution of the right pleural effusion with only a minimal trace fluid remaining. There
 is no change in left pleural effusion and the position of the pigtail
 catheter.  There is an increase in the vascularity of the perihilar areas
 consistent with worsening of the pulmonary edema currently mild to moderate.

 DL

         DR. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 47**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 48**]

value.text:
Assessment:
   Pt arrived form the ED on Levophed, her Baseline Bp is about
   80-90-occas lower after HD days.Repeat chest imaging shows resolution of the previously noted right pleural effusion, with only a minimal trace fluid remaining.
There is marked resolution of the right pleural effusion with only a minimal trace fluid remaining.
